description.narrative: Dissemination of E&S standards: IFC''s participation in this project would support a leading Brazilian asset manager with the capacity to implement and promote good environmental and social standards for the corporate sector in Brazil. Furthermore, given that the GÃ¡vea Group is a standard setter in Brazil in many respects, the potential replication effect may be significant, leveraging IFC''s market impact. Access to Finance and turnaround: IFC will facilitate the restructuring and refinancing of financially stressed middle market companies, keeping assets in productive use, as well as providing much needed liquidity and risk capital for the local marketplace. In addition, GÃ¡vea Credito''s involvement with a client through the Fund can immediately improve the financial profile of the company and in and of itself provide a stamp of approval, opening up access to other lenders and investors. Job preservation: As IFC has learned from similar DARP projects in Europe and Asia, as well as from the turnaround and restructuring of its own portfolio companies (especially during the Asian and Argentine crisis), a major consequence of resolving special situations is saving and eventually creating jobs, which carries significant and positive benefits. Based on the current pipeline of companies in the Fund''s pipeline, the Project could preserve thousands of jobs and lead to the creation of many more in Brazil. International Best Practices: IFC''s participation in the Project, coupled with a strong package of turnaround guidelines, would provide a model for creating a special situations resolution mechanism and can promote best practices in local markets in Brazil and Latin America.

The Project supports Gávea Credito Estruturados plans to launch an innovative investment vehicle to provide long-term financing for middle market Brazilian firms in need of financial restructuring and without access to the capital markets, promoting (i) competition and innovation by introducing an innovative financing vehicle into the Brazilian market and (ii) capacity-building with a leading alternative asset management firm that can be followed as an example to future deals in other Latin American markets.
